At the Court at Buckingham Palace, the 26th day of February, 1934. Present, The King’s Most Excellent Majesty in Council. Whereas by an Order of His Majesty in Council bearing date the 14th day of July, 1921, and entitled the Eastern African Court of Appeal Order in Council, 1921 ( a ) (in this Order referred to as “ the Principal Order ”), a Court, called His Majesty’s Court of Appeal for Eastern Africa (in this Order referred to as “ the Court of Appeal ”), was constituted for the hearing and determining of appeals from His Majesty’s Courts in the Colony and Protectorate of Kenya, the Uganda Protectorate, the Nyasaland Protectorate, the Zanzibar Protectorate and the Tanganyika Territory : And whereas by treaty, grant, usage, sufferance, and other lawful means, His Majesty the King has power and jurisdiction in Ethiopia, and His Britannic Majesty’s Court for Ethiopia is a British Court in a foreign country : And whereas it is expedient that provision should be made under section 9 of the Foreign Jurisdiction Act, 1890,(b) for the hearing and determining of appeals from His Britannic Majesty’s Court for Ethiopia by the Court of Appeal : Now, therefore, His Majesty, by virtue and in exercise of the powers in this behalf by the Foreign Jurisdiction Act, 1890, or otherwise in His Majesty vested is pleased, by and with the advice of His Privy Council, to order and it is hereby ordered, as follows :— (a) S.R. & O. 1921 (No. 1210) p. 262. mods.abstract: Correspondence, memoranda, minute papers, and notes concerning the drafting of the Ethiopia Order in Council. The papers cover interdepartmental discussion between officials at the Foreign Office, India Office, Government of India (Foreign and Political Department), and the Legal Adviser to the Ethiopian Government over the articles of the order.The file includes draft copies of the order made in 1931 (folios 137-38) and 1934 (folios 22-49) and associated memoranda by William Eric Beckett, Legal Adviser at the Foreign Office (folios 94-136 and 8-20).
